g.text: Department of Psychology, University of Gothenburg, Gothenburg, Sweden,
Department of Psychology, California State University San Marcos, San Marcos, CA, United States
Climate change is primarily driven by human-caused greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions,
and may therefore be mitigated by changes to human behavior (
). Despite efforts to raise awareness and concern about climate change, GHG
). Climate change seems to be at odds with the
immediate, present threats to which humans are adapted to cope (
). In contrast to immediate dangers, climate change
is typically abstract, large scale, slow and often unrelated to the welfare of our daily
). But there are moments when the
consequences of climate change are readily apparent, such as extreme weather events.
In the current paper, we examine the impact of personal experience with an extreme
weather event, and the impact of this experience on beliefs about climate change, and
intentions to take actions that can help prepare for and mitigate the consequences of
Keywords: pro-environmental, environmental concerns, attitudes, extreme weather and climate events, hurrican,
Experiencing natural disasters can aï¬ect people both physically and psychologically. Past research
have shown howexperiencing natural disasters can aï¬ect public health outcomes such as mortality,
injuries, infectious diseases, economic impact, and produce a range of psychosocial consequences
). Natural disasters such as hurricanes, earthquakes, and ï¬oods can lead to
post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety disorders, and even elevated rates of

related to environmental risk perception. Similarly,
more likely to make pro-environmental donations after interpreting local temperature increases
as evidence for global warming (see also

). A recent meta-analysis found that self-reported
experiences with extreme weather only had a small positive eï¬ect on belief in climate change, while
